0.Prompt: Do we live in a simulation?
0.Response:
nobody knows for sure.
but there are some theories that say we do.
1) There is a mathematical formula called the Boltzmann brain theory which says that there are many universes out there, and they all have their own time lines, but most of them are very similar to ours. So it’s possible that somewhere in one of those time lines a “random” series of events may create just the conditions required for you and I (or me at least) to exist.
2) The simulation hypothesis is based on the idea that we live in a computer generated world, where everything around us from planets and galaxies all the way down to every grain of sand, even to things as tiny as an electron can be just numbers stored somewhere. So it’s possible that someone out there is manipulating these numbers into existence for some unknown reason.
3) There are a lot of people who believe in God, but not necessarily in the traditional sense. They think that we live in one big computer generated world created by this unnamed deity for our enjoyment or perhaps for it’s own entertainment and so on. So it’s possible that there is some kind of super intelligent being out there who has programmed

1.Prompt: What is the nature of consciousness?
1.Response:
Is it just an epiphenomenal, emergent, non-causally dependent process that has no causal power and no real existence apart from the brain? Or is it a real, independent, causally powerful entity that survives at the very limit and/or despite dis-units and interstices between death-residuals which occur across levels and perspectivizations during an apparent sleep and throughout reconfiguring memorial/intercessions following clinically intolerable, life-threatening events?
 beskrev i detalj i boken The Ego Tunnel: The Secret Back Door in to the Conscious Mind (2014).

2.Prompt: What is the nature of reality?
2.Response:
sierpirino 2018-03-27T14:56:09+00:00
The question of what constitutes reality has been asked for centuries. It is a fundamental question, because it deals with that which constitutes experience of everything, even experience of consciousness. One definition from one person, which makes little or no sense to anyone else in terms of explaining why their conceptual framework would give any significance at all to anything described as the objective physical universe or ‘the world’ is a form of reality.
In order for something to be considered real it must be an objectively verifiable fact. This means that it can be verified by someone who has not experienced it, and that it can be verified by anyone else who experiences it in the same way as the first person did. In other words, if I say “I saw a man walking down the street” then you must be able to verify this statement by observing the same thing for yourself.
The problem with this definition is that it assumes there are only two possibilities: either something exists or does not exist at all! But what about things like dreams? Or even hallucinations – could these also be considered real
